author: mklement0
body:
<sup>Follow-up from #6357 and #6436.</sup>


PSv3 brought unified handling of scalars and collections, allowing indexing even into scalars; e.g., `$a = 1; $a[0]`

However, using an out-of-bounds index results in different behavior depending on whether the value being accessed is a scalar or a collection:

* scalars: `[System.Management.Automation.Internal.AutomationNull]::Value`
* collections: `$null`

What is the reason for this discrepancy?
Can it be eliminated?

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
# Define a single-element array variable and a scalar variable.
$array = , 1; $scalar = 1
# Access out-of-bounds index 1 on both
# and test if the value is a null collection ([System.Management.Automation.Internal.AutomationNull]::Value)
$null -eq $array[1] -and @($array[1]).Count -eq 0
$null -eq $scalar[1] -and @($scalar[1]).Count -eq 0
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
False
False
```

That is, (scalar) `$null` should be returned in both cases.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
False
True
```

That is, in the scalar case `[System.Management.Automation.Internal.AutomationNull]::Value` was returned.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.4
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; Version 1709, OS Build: 16299.371)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.16299.251 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; Version 1709, OS Build: 16299.371)
```

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body:
In scalar operations, this difference is is effectively unnoticeable since `AutomationNull` gets converted to `$null` in a value context:
```
PS[1] (154) > (1)[1] -eq $null
True
```
However in an array operation, `AutomationNull` is treated like an empty array so this `1,2,3 + (1)[1]` results in an array of three elements and  this `1,2,3 + @(1)[1]` results in an array with 4 elements.

I'm on the fence as to which is the "better" behaviour (note: strict mode prevents out-of-bound indexing but with different errors for arrays (out-of-bounds) and scalars ('Unable to index into an object of type System.Int32.'))

Also, if this affects many people, we don't want to change things due to the risk of breaking them. And if it doesn't affect anyone then it doesn't matter whether we change it or not (other than the 'ick' factor of course.)

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
That's helpful background information, @BrucePay.

---

Leaving backward-compatibility issues aside:

> I'm on the fence as to which is the "better" behaviour

While it's fundamentally tricky to speculate about the properties of nonexistent entities, I think it makes more sense to think of the elements of an array as _scalars_ by default (rather than assuming _nesting_ of arrays).

Since `$null` is the _scalar_ "not-a-value", it makes sense to me to default to that and to confine `[System.Management.Automation.Internal.AutomationNull]::Value` - the "null _collection_" , the "no-values-to-enumerate" value - to situations where _collections_ are expected.

---

As for backward compatibility:

> Also, if this affects many people, we don't want to change things due to the risk of breaking them.

At least to me it's hard to see how someone would have found value in the current behavior and therefore _relied_ on it, especially given its inconsistency.

In short: probably a [Bucket 3: Unlikely Grey Area](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/dev-process/breaking-change-contract.md#bucket-3-unlikely-grey-area) change (though that is just a _guess_).

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: @mklement0 Yes - bucket is 3 probably right. Which also means that fixing it won't impact people much either way - no breaks but little benefit. Still - it would be nice to be consistent.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@BrucePay:

> Still - it would be nice to be consistent.

Indeed, and the corollaries of that are:

* no head-scratching by new users stumbling upon the behavior.

* no subtle bugs in future code (perhaps unlikely, but definitely possible; e.g., expecting `$var[0], $var[1] | % { "[$_]" }` to always output _2_ objects).

title: Out-of-bounds indexed access works differently with collections than with scalars
